Award.AwardTitle: Capacity Expansion and Imaging/ Data Capture at the Herbarium of the University of Alaska Museum (ALA)
Award.AbstractNarration: A grant has been awarded to the University of Alaska Museum (ALA) under the direction of Dr. Stefanie Ickert-Bond to incorporate 32,000 specimens of arctic and boreal plants from the J.P. Anderson Collection, recently acquired from Iowa State University. ALA has the largest collection of plant specimens from the Beringia Province. During the Pleistocene Ice Age, this region was free of ice, providing a refuge for terrestrial organisms on the Bering Land "Bridge" and a means by which plants could disperse between Asia and North America. This project will produce an online database with 190,000 digital images of herbarium specimens. Innovative digital tools will be used to automate the capture of data from labels on the herbarium sheets, and to implement an object-tracking system through the use of barcode labels. The data will be added to the Global Biodiversity Information Facility, MorphBank, and GenBank. The University of Alaska Museum will organize a workshop for K-12 teachers and students to highlight the utility of living plants in the region as educational tools and to encourage an interest in plants through hands-on activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the development of the University of Alaska Museum’s Herbarium, which is one the World’s major collections of far-northern plants.  NSF funds were used to physically expand the archival space by 42%, and to get specimen-by-specimen data and specimen images from the collection onto the Internet.

The worldwide capture of digital data from biological collections, gathered over centuries, is a goal that will expedite understanding of major issues in biodiversity, but the backlog of digitally unrecorded botanical specimens in the U.S is probably about ninety million.  Such a number defies conventional methods of data capture, such as keyboarding, and our project successfully demonstrated one approach to expeditiously eliminating the global backlog.  While about 90,000 of our herbarium’s 185,000 specimens were already well represented and accessible to students and researchers via the Internet, we still faced a long and tedious task.  But in comparison with other biological specimens, herbarium sheets (pressed plants) are of nearly uniform size and essentially two dimensional.  These features make photography of specimens efficient.  Also, labels are glued to the sheets, so most specimen data is text within each photograph.  

Three undergraduate students, using a digital camera on a copy stand, plus an attached computer and bar-code scanner, were able to photograph most of the collection in a summer, with the work trailing off in the following academic year.  During that first summer, 1000 to 1500 specimens were photographed per day.  Some four terabytes of digital photographs are now stored at the Texas Advanced Computing Center (U Texas, Austin) and accessible through the Arctos online database (http://arctos.database.musuem/uam_herb).  The 90,000 previously digitized and online specimen records are now complimented by high-resolution photographs, and 165,000 images have been processed with optical-character-recognition (OCR) software, which attempts to interpret text in each image.  Though the OCR product is of uneven quality, it can be (and is) searched online, thereby providing fair access to the previously un-digitized material, including their images.

Colleagues at the University of Arizona are now using “natural language processing” (NLP, a form of artificial intelligence and learning) in an attempt to parse our OCR product into standard data fields.  This effort benefits from having the OCR from the 90,000 already standardized records.  The overreaching goal is to provide a complete protocol for attacking the huge global backlog of un-digitized botanical specimens.
